recordings.rmk: Calls from pair on territory.

recordings.type: We her the bird landing in the water at the end of the recording, flight call
recordings.rmk:
Recorded with my ZOOM H5 Handy recorder. High pass filter applied with Audacity

Not the first time in the lake, looks to be a pair going to nest in the lake. Someone told me that the Red-throated loon is not eating from the lake they are nesting in.

Last time they took off doing two loops around the lake and disappearing. 10 minutes later I could hear them again.

They were coming back and the same thing. Making noise approaching the lake, then quiet and starting the sound again when they come in for landing.

First time I chanced on getting pictures and today I had both my camera and recorder ready. I will record the bird as long as it is making noise and then I will change to my camera.

End of the recording and we hear the birds land, almost at the same time


[Picture 1](http://www.aladdin.st/bird-watching/sweden/321.jpg)

[Picture 2](http://www.aladdin.st/bird-watching/sweden/322.jpg)

[Picture 3](http://www.aladdin.st/bird-watching/sweden/323.jpg)

[Picture 4](http://www.aladdin.st/bird-watching/sweden/324.jpg)

Site located on an expansive floodplain 70 meters east of the Kamishak River, and about 3 km upstream from Akumwarvik Bay. Low, densely-vegetated coastal mountains rise 2.5 km to the east. Viereck Class III.A.2.a Bluejoint meadow.

Site located on the southern coast of Kamishak Bay near the mouth of Douglas River. Located about 88 meters from the back shore, which is then another 30 - 90 meters from the surf zone. Low bluffs ring the site to the east and southeast at about 1.3 km distance. Viereck Class III.B.2.b. Mesic Herbaceous Fireweed.
